episode.title: U. S. Term Limits, Inc. v. Thornton

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: We'll hear argument now in Number 93-1456, U.S. Term Limits, Inc., v. Ray Thornton, 93-1828, Consolidated, Winston Bryant v. Bobbie E. Hill.
General Bryant.

turn.speaker: j_winston_bryant
turn.label: Mr. J. Winston Bryant
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court:
The State of Arkansas is before this Court today defending its constitutional authority to encourage rotation in office of its congressional delegation.
Amendment 73, which would have accomplished that objective was ruled unconstitutional by the Arkansas supreme court.
The court held that Amendment 73 amounted to a qualification and, further, that the State of Arkansas could not add additional qualifications to those listed in Article I, sections 2 and 3.
We disagree with that ruling.
Amendment 73 is not a qualification, but even if it is a qualification, the State of Arkansas has the authority to add additional qualifications to those listed in Article I, sections 2 and 3.

Our Founding Fathers envisioned a Congress of citizen legislators who would serve awhile, return and xx with the people, and not stay in office indefinitely, and during the 18th and 19th Centuries, voluntary rotation was a common practice.
During the 20th Century, we have seen a dramatic increase in the number of long-term, entrenched incumbents.
Entrenched incumbency makes for an electoral system that is less fair, less competitive, and less representative.
Amendment 73 was adopted in 1992 by the people of Arkansas overwhelmingly, by a 60 percent to 40 percen majority.
Twenty-two States now have some form of term limit proposals or ballot access initiatives on their books.
Thirty-seven States have term limits that limit the terms of the executive branch officials of those States or the legislative branch officials of those States.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Is the theory that by this rotation the policy that the legislators adopt will be different one system than in the other system?
That is to say, are there policy implications electing an incumbent as opposed to a nonincumbent?

turn.speaker: j_winston_bryant
turn.label: Mr. J. Winston Bryant
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, that is correct.
That issue is not before this Court, however, but the people of Arkansas, by Amendment 73, have decided to encourage rotation in office to make the election process more fair and more competitive.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, but you're explaining the rationale for the limitation, and I'm asking if part of that rationale is that rotated representatives will vote differently than incumbents would have, would shape public policy in a different way.

turn.speaker: j_winston_bryant
turn.label: Mr. J. Winston Bryant
turn.text: Your Honor, they would be more beholden to the people under the theory of Amendment 73 because they would not be career politicians.
They would be more responsive to the people.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: So there would be a difference in the kind and the shape and the policies of the legislation that they would enact.

turn.speaker: j_winston_bryant
turn.label: Mr. J. Winston Bryant
turn.text: There could be, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, is that the justification for the rule, or isn't it?

turn.speaker: j_winston_bryant
turn.label: Mr. J. Winston Bryant
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
Amendment 73 provides for strict term limits for certain State elected officials in Arkansas.
It denies ballot access to multiterm congressional incumbents, but does allow those incumbents, after serving a maximum number of terms allowed by Amendment 73, to run as a write-in candidate.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: But once they're denied the ballot access, they're denied it for life, is that right?

turn.speaker: j_winston_bryant
turn.label: Mr. J. Winston Bryant
turn.text: That is correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Doesn't the permanency of the denial carry a suggestion of what we would normally refer to as a qualification?

turn.speaker: j_winston_bryant
turn.label: Mr. J. Winston Bryant
turn.text: No, Your Honor.

The definition of a ballot access proposal like Amendment 73 as opposed to a qualification is put forth in our brief, and that is, a qualification is something that absolutely prohibits a candidate from serving even if elected.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well, I realize that's your position, but in any case, your position would take us beyond Storer, wouldn't it?

turn.speaker: j_winston_bryant
turn.label: Mr. J. Winston Bryant
turn.text: No, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well, in Storer... maybe my recollection is wrong.
In Storer, I thought there wasn't a lifetime disqualification.

turn.speaker: j_winston_bryant
turn.label: Mr. J. Winston Bryant
turn.text: That is correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: I mean, if you... you know, had been party-affiliated within a certain period of time, you couldn't be there as an independent, but the next election was coming, and that was a new day.
Isn't that right, in Storer?

turn.speaker: j_winston_bryant
turn.label: Mr. J. Winston Bryant
turn.text: That is correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: So Storer didn't have that implication of permanence which is in fact a feature of the Arkansas system.

turn.speaker: j_winston_bryant
turn.label: Mr. J. Winston Bryant
turn.text: That is correct, Your Honor, but the State's position is that Amendment 73 is consistent with Storer, the difference being that under Amendment 73 a candidate can actually serve a couple of terms in the Senate, or three terms in the House, so it does not absolutely prohibit a candidate from serving.
After that candidate reaches a maximum number of terms, then obviously that candidate is denied access to the ballot.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: General--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --precedent, any case where a group based on past experience, past lawful experience, has been categorically hobbled in this way.
It's not simply a handicap in the race if the only access they have is as a write-in, is it?

turn.speaker: j_winston_bryant
turn.label: Mr. J. Winston Bryant
turn.text: Your Honor, to answer your question, the State does not take the position that Amendment 73 is an absolute handicap, because we're dealing with multiterm incumbents who would have great name recognition, resources available to them that ordinary challenges would not have.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: I'm trying to contrast a mere handicap from a hobbling, and it seems to me this falls in the latter category.

turn.speaker: j_winston_bryant
turn.label: Mr. J. Winston Bryant
turn.text: No, Your Honor.

The State's position is that Amendment 73 will allow a candidate to serve even if elected, and under that scenario, under that definition that we put forth to this Court, would amount to only a ballot access regulation.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, General Bryant, a good many States have passed so-called term limit measures that just disable a candidate from appearing on the ballot for a short period of time, isn't that correct?

turn.speaker: j_winston_bryant
turn.label: Mr. J. Winston Bryant
turn.text: That is correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: And Arkansas has a very different provision in that it extends for the rest of that particular candidate's life.

turn.speaker: j_winston_bryant
turn.label: Mr. J. Winston Bryant
turn.text: That is correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Do you think that there may well be, even if you are correct that it is seen as a ballot access measure, that there may be First Amendment issues at stake here, the associational rights, for instance, of the political party that might want to have the candidate on the ballot as its candidate?

turn.speaker: j_winston_bryant
turn.label: Mr. J. Winston Bryant
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, there are--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: And are those issues issues that were resolved in the courts below?

turn.speaker: j_winston_bryant
turn.label: Mr. J. Winston Bryant
turn.text: --No, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: So that would be open on remand, I assume, even if we agreed with you it were a ballot access measure?

turn.speaker: j_winston_bryant
turn.label: Mr. J. Winston Bryant
turn.text: That is correct, Your Honor.
That is correct.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Those... you say the First Amendment issue were presented to the supreme court of Arkansas but not decided by it.

turn.speaker: j_winston_bryant
turn.label: Mr. J. Winston Bryant
turn.text: That is correct, Your Honor.
Amendment 73 is also consistent with this Court's jurisprudence.
In Burdick v. Takushi, a case from Hawaii, in that particular case, the State of Hawaii had adopted a statutory scheme that allowed write-in voting to be completely banned.
In this--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Yes, and what about a State like Hawaii that has no write-in voting allowed at all?

turn.speaker: j_winston_bryant
turn.label: Mr. J. Winston Bryant
turn.text: --Your Honor--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Would it become a qualification then?

turn.speaker: j_winston_bryant
turn.label: Mr. J. Winston Bryant
turn.text: --It would become a qualification at that point, if there is no write-in provision, but even assuming--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: How is that?
I'm not sure how that makes it a qualification.

It seems to me the test for whether it's a qualification is whether, when a person has been supposedly elected and reports to Congress, Congress can sit in judgment and say, this person is not qualified.
Now, if that should happen, what disqualification would there be?

turn.speaker: j_winston_bryant
turn.label: Mr. J. Winston Bryant
turn.text: --Your Honor, under that scenario, Congress can consider the... obviously can consider under Article I, section 5, the qualifications, and under the position of the State in this particular case, a pure write-in, a pure term limits proposal--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Let's assume in Hawaii the person gets on the ballot by mistake, or in Arkansas.
An incumbent who has no right to be on the ballot is put on the ballot and gets elected, all right.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Reports to Congress.
Now, could Congress sit in judgment and exclude that person?

turn.speaker: j_winston_bryant
turn.label: Mr. J. Winston Bryant
turn.text: --Yes, Your Honor.
Under Article I, section 5, if the person were not properly qualified, yes.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well then it is a qualification in Arkansas.
Do you say that if somebody gets on the ballot by mistake in Arkansas and is elected, Congress can exclude that person?

turn.speaker: j_winston_bryant
turn.label: Mr. J. Winston Bryant
turn.text: Your Honor, I was considering it under a pure term limits proposal.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I'm not talking about--

turn.speaker: j_winston_bryant
turn.label: Mr. J. Winston Bryant
turn.text: Under Amendment--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --I'm talking about, Hawaii exclusion from the ballot system.
It's not a term limit proposal, it's just exclusion from the ballot, but entirely.
No write-in allowed, either, and the Arkansas system.

turn.speaker: j_winston_bryant
turn.label: Mr. J. Winston Bryant
turn.text: --And under the Arkansas system, Your Honor, the Congress could not consider the Amendment 73 proposal as a qualification under that scenario.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: It seems to me they couldn't with respect to Hawaii, either.
Hawaii doesn't say you shall not serve, it just says you shall not get on the ballot, and people will not be able to vote for you.

turn.speaker: j_winston_bryant
turn.label: Mr. J. Winston Bryant
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: And if that happens, you're not unqualified.

turn.speaker: j_winston_bryant
turn.label: Mr. J. Winston Bryant
turn.text: That is correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Could I ask you... you say that this is not a qualification.
Is it a time, place or manner restriction?

turn.speaker: j_winston_bryant
turn.label: Mr. J. Winston Bryant
turn.text: Yes, it is, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: It is.
Is there such a thing as something that is neither the one nor the other, it is neither a qualification nor a time, place and manner restriction?

turn.speaker: j_winston_bryant
turn.label: Mr. J. Winston Bryant
turn.text: Neither a qualifica... no, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: It's either one or the other.

turn.speaker: j_winston_bryant
turn.label: Mr. J. Winston Bryant
turn.text: It's either one--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Everything falls into one or the other category.

turn.speaker: j_winston_bryant
turn.label: Mr. J. Winston Bryant
turn.text: --According to our--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Which category would a law providing that you only count half the votes of a candidate fall?
Would that be a qualification or a time, place and manner?
[Laughter]
Or maybe something different?

turn.speaker: j_winston_bryant
turn.label: Mr. J. Winston Bryant
turn.text: --That would probably fall under time, place, and manner, Your Honor, but--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Time, place, and manner?
Which of the three?
Is it time, place, or manner?
[Laughter]

turn.speaker: j_winston_bryant
turn.label: Mr. J. Winston Bryant
turn.text: --It would be the manner.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: The manner, okay.

turn.speaker: j_winston_bryant
turn.label: Mr. J. Winston Bryant
turn.text: But, Your Honor, that would have to undergo First and Fourteenth Amendment scrutiny if that proposal were adopted by the State.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: If it's time, place, and manner, this means, of course, that the current Congress, composed mainly of incumbents, can simply revise the Arkansas law right?

turn.speaker: j_winston_bryant
turn.label: Mr. J. Winston Bryant
turn.text: That is correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: And indeed, the current Congress could revise those laws that don't provide for term limitations or don't provide for exclusion from ballot access to incumbents.

turn.speaker: j_winston_bryant
turn.label: Mr. J. Winston Bryant
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor,--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: So in effect you could have the Federal legislature doing something that discourages... that discourages incumbency.

turn.speaker: j_winston_bryant
turn.label: Mr. J. Winston Bryant
turn.text: --Yes, Your Honor, under Article 1, section 4.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: What could the Federal legislature do?

turn.speaker: j_winston_bryant
turn.label: Mr. J. Winston Bryant
turn.text: The Federal legislature, Your Honor, is given authority under Article I, section 4, to override anything the States do in the area.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Yes, but are you suggesting that it could do... the Federal legislature could do anything more than simply negate a State regulation?

turn.speaker: j_winston_bryant
turn.label: Mr. J. Winston Bryant
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: And what would be the authority for that?

turn.speaker: j_winston_bryant
turn.label: Mr. J. Winston Bryant
turn.text: Article I, section 4 would give Congress that authority, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: To do more than just negate a State regulation?

turn.speaker: j_winston_bryant
turn.label: Mr. J. Winston Bryant
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: And what part of the language is it of that section that--

turn.speaker: j_winston_bryant
turn.label: Mr. J. Winston Bryant
turn.text: The term 4, has a very broad, expansive meaning, and during the ratification debates the States were concerned about the fact that under Article I, section 4, Congress was being given the authority which the States concluded would allow Congress to override anything the States did in the area.

The Article I, section 4 clause was sold on the basis that Congress needed the authority or power to preserve its... the Union, if necessary, and so Article I, section 4 has a... is very broad in its meaning, and would authorize Congress to adopt legislation in the area.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: --So that even though, perhaps, a State hasn't acted, Congress could, by law, make regulations governing the time, place, and manner?

turn.speaker: j_winston_bryant
turn.label: Mr. J. Winston Bryant
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, and in fact Congress could override amendment 73 if Congress so desired.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But what if Arkansas had made no provision for term limits at all, could Congress step in and make a provision for term limits?

turn.speaker: j_winston_bryant
turn.label: Mr. J. Winston Bryant
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, under Article I, section 4, Congress could do that.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: You've mentioned that there were qualifications that don't come from the Constitution itself.
You started out your argument by saying the States could add qualifications.

Now you've told us that there are only two categories, there's qualifications, and there's time, place, and manner, but you see two categories of qualifications, I gather, because you've told us that some come from the Constitution, and then there are others the States can add.
So what's the category of qualifications, extra-Constitution, that the State can add that are not time, place, and manner regulations?

turn.speaker: j_winston_bryant
turn.label: Mr. J. Winston Bryant
turn.text: Your Honor, the qualifications that the States could add would all be time, place, and manner under Article I, section 4.

Also the State could, if there are some enumerated... if Article I, section 4 does not cover some particular areas, Amendment 10 would allow the States to act in that particular area, but the States have always added additional qualifications.
In fact, when the Constitution was adopted by the States, the State of Virginia had a property qualification as well as a residency requirement.
James Madison--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: If you call those qualifications, can the State override them?

turn.speaker: j_winston_bryant
turn.label: Mr. J. Winston Bryant
turn.text: --No, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: So the--

turn.speaker: j_winston_bryant
turn.label: Mr. J. Winston Bryant
turn.text: I'm sorry--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --Pardon me, can the Congress override them?

turn.speaker: j_winston_bryant
turn.label: Mr. J. Winston Bryant
turn.text: --Yes, Your Honor, the Congress could under Article--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: So anything the State adds as either a qualification or a time, place, and manner can be overridden by the Congress?

turn.speaker: j_winston_bryant
turn.label: Mr. J. Winston Bryant
turn.text: --Your Honor, the specific provisions that can be overridden by Congress are the Article I, section 4 grants of authority to the States by--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, are there some qualifications that the State can add, and I... this was suggested by Justice Ginsburg's question, that cannot be overridden by the Congress?

turn.speaker: j_winston_bryant
turn.label: Mr. J. Winston Bryant
turn.text: --None comes to mind, Your Honor.
The States--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: General Bryant--
--Well, why--
--the Congress can't impose any qualifications, can it?

turn.speaker: j_winston_bryant
turn.label: Mr. J. Winston Bryant
turn.text: --Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Oh.

turn.speaker: j_winston_bryant
turn.label: Mr. J. Winston Bryant
turn.text: Congress can impose additional qualifications.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: What's the source for that?
Where do you find the authority for that?

turn.speaker: j_winston_bryant
turn.label: Mr. J. Winston Bryant
turn.text: Article 1, section 4.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: That doesn't talk about qualifications.
That talks about time, place, and manner.

turn.speaker: j_winston_bryant
turn.label: Mr. J. Winston Bryant
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, but under our definition the Congress can add additional qualifications based on Article 1, section 4 authority, and Congress has done so since the very first Congress.
In the very first Congress--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: You think Congress could pass a statute saying every Senator must be at least 50 years old?

turn.speaker: j_winston_bryant
turn.label: Mr. J. Winston Bryant
turn.text: --Congress could pass--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: What's your answer?

turn.speaker: j_winston_bryant
turn.label: Mr. J. Winston Bryant
turn.text: --Yes.
Yes, Your Honor, they could pass such a statute sub... of course, it would be subject to First and Fifth Amendment.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Now, where do you get that?
You don't get that from the Tenth Amendment.
Where does that come from?

turn.speaker: j_winston_bryant
turn.label: Mr. J. Winston Bryant
turn.text: That comes under Article I, section 4 authority, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: But that's time, place, and manner, not qualifications.
I thought you make a distinction between the two.
You make no distinction between time, place, and manner and qualifications?

turn.speaker: j_winston_bryant
turn.label: Mr. J. Winston Bryant
turn.text: Yes, we make a distinction, Your Honor.
The... the narrow--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well, you must be... 50 has nothing to do with time, place, and manner of elections at all.
It has to do purely with qualifications.

turn.speaker: j_winston_bryant
turn.label: Mr. J. Winston Bryant
turn.text: --The narrow issue before this Court is whether or not Amendment 73 amounts to a ballot access regulation.
If it amounts to a qualification, the States as well as Congress can add additional qualifications to those listed in Article--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well, I can understand why you argue the States can on the basis of the Tenth Amendment.
I don't know where the Congress gets the power to do that.

turn.speaker: j_winston_bryant
turn.label: Mr. J. Winston Bryant
turn.text: --And that is under Article 1, section 4, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: But that doesn't relate to qualifications, that relates to time, place, and manner.
Is there no qualification that is not a time, place, and manner provision?
Every qualification is a time, place, and manner provision?

turn.speaker: j_winston_bryant
turn.label: Mr. J. Winston Bryant
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, that would be consistent with the State's position.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Every qualification--

turn.speaker: j_winston_bryant
turn.label: Mr. J. Winston Bryant
turn.text: Under that--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --is a time, place, and manner provision.

turn.speaker: j_winston_bryant
turn.label: Mr. J. Winston Bryant
turn.text: --Under that theory we advance.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: How is the age qualification a time, place, and manner?
How would a qualification that every elected Senator must have a college degree, how is that a time, place, and manner qualification or condition?

turn.speaker: j_winston_bryant
turn.label: Mr. J. Winston Bryant
turn.text: Oh, Your Honor, that is a time, place, and manner because if the State of Arkansas or Congress did that, that would be... that is constitutional, according to our position, under Article I, section 4.
However, it would have to pass constitutional muster, and that is the test.
Under the ballot access--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: That is a manner condition, as it were?

turn.speaker: j_winston_bryant
turn.label: Mr. J. Winston Bryant
turn.text: --Yes, Your Honor.
That could be considered a manner condition under Article I, section 4.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, General Bryant, this is a very remarkable proposition--
[Laughter]
--and... does your argument depend in any way on this most unusual interpretation?

turn.speaker: j_winston_bryant
turn.label: Mr. J. Winston Bryant
turn.text: Your Honor, the State's argument is that Amendment 73 amounts to a ballot access regulation.
That is the narrow issue that this Court can reach.

If Amendment 73 does in fact amount to a qualification as determined by this Court, then it's the State's position that the State of Arkansas can add additional qualifications under Article I, section 4 to those enumerated in the Constitution.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: But what we're interested to know is, does it follow from that that the Congress could not override that qualification?
Where does the Constitution give the Congress authority to override qualifications?

turn.speaker: j_winston_bryant
turn.label: Mr. J. Winston Bryant
turn.text: Because, Your Honor, that qualification would be adopted under Article I, section 4.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, but then we're right back where we're--

turn.speaker: j_winston_bryant
turn.label: Mr. J. Winston Bryant
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --Let's assume that we tell you that under the Constitution we think there are two things, two semantic, two juridical categories, one qualifications and the other time, place, and manner.

Now, if you say, and if you assume that we hold that term limit is a qualification, we are exploring whether or not the Congress could override that, and you say, oh, well, they can go under section 4, but we've just stipulated this is a qualification, and that doesn't apply to section 4.

turn.speaker: j_winston_bryant
turn.label: Mr. J. Winston Bryant
turn.text: Under that--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: And the gravamen of the argument is it would be very strange to allow Congress to override a time, place, and manner regulation, but not to override a greater restriction, which is a qualification, and you're not answering that argument because you keep resorting to Article I, section 4, but that's a very odd interpretation.

turn.speaker: j_winston_bryant
turn.label: Mr. J. Winston Bryant
turn.text: --Your Honor, under that scenario, then the States would have the authority under Amendment 10.
Congress would not have the authority under your scenario to add additional qualifications.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: On that assumption, may we put the question directly that Justice Kennedy alluded to?

Isn't there something very odd in a scheme in which the... we'll say the comparatively less important conditions that fall under time, place, and manner can be overridden by Congress, and yet the presumably more fundamental conditions known as qualifications would be left entirely to the States?
If they couldn't trust the States on time, place, and manner, wouldn't it be odd if they trusted the States on qualifications?

turn.speaker: j_winston_bryant
turn.label: Mr. J. Winston Bryant
turn.text: That is correct, Your Honor.

Under the jurisprudence of this Court, ballot access jurisprudence, the States can erect barriers or limitations to limit the field of candidates, and so long as that passes constitutional muster, then the States have the authority to do that.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Or you might have responded that perhaps they were willing to trust the Federal Congress with respect to the relatively minor matters of time, place, and manner--
[Laughter]
--but not willing to trust the Federal Congress with respect to the greater matter of qualifications.
That's a possibility, isn't it?

turn.speaker: j_winston_bryant
turn.label: Mr. J. Winston Bryant
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
[Laughter]

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Mr. Kester, we'll hear from you.

turn.speaker: john_g_kester
turn.label: Mr. John G. Kester
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:
I'd like to start out, I think, by introducing--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Mr. Kester, do you adopt the same argument as your predecessor here about everything is either a qualification or a time, place, and manner?

turn.speaker: john_g_kester
turn.label: Mr. John G. Kester
turn.text: --No, not precisely, Justice O'Connor.

I think that the question that several members of the Court have been putting really illuminates the constitutional structure that we're talking about here, and the argument that is being made by the opponents of Amendment 73, first of all skipping over and pretending that it's a legal incapacity when it's nothing of the kind... it's a less restrictive alternative that the State has adopted, but skipping over that and accepting the pretense that this is a limitation on service in the Congress, you're then put to the task of fitting together some provisions of the Constitution.
What does the Constitution say with respect to the power of Congress to adopt, say, a term limits provision and apply it to the States?
I think the answer to that has to begin by looking at the sources of power of Congress and of the States, and they are very different.

Congress has power only insofar as it is granted in the Constitution, and the only grant of power to Congress to legislate in this area has to come from Article I, section 4, or, I quickly amend, the Necessary and Proper Clause, which is also part of Article I, section 4, and nowadays section 5 of the Fifteenth Amendment, which has received a very, very broad interpretation, and I don't think that we need to address that at this time, but we recognize that that's very broad.
The sources of power of the State are very, very different, and particularly when you have legislation, a constitutional amendment that the people of Arkansas adopted and imposed on themselves.
They're not reaching out... this is not a State trying to regulate interstate commerce in other States.
This is a law which, if anything, hurts the people of Arkansas.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, Mr. Kester, let me ask you this, do you this Congress has the power under Article I, section 4, to adopt precisely the kind of law that Arkansas has applicable to all States?

turn.speaker: john_g_kester
turn.label: Mr. John G. Kester
turn.text: No.
My answer would be no, it does not, for the following reason.

I would say, in the first instance, if you take the words of Article I, section 4, "make or alter", and say that those are of equal force, and I'm not sure that you have to do that at all, I would say Congress has the power to knock out any State law with respect to elections that Congress doesn't like.
It's very, very clear that that's why Article I, section 4 was put in the Constitution.
But once you have the law passed, once you have the authority of Congress to do that exercise, that's not the end of the exercise, that's just the beginning.
This Court pointed that out in Williams v. Rhodes.
There may be power there, but then, has the power been properly exercised?
First of all, it would obviously be subject to attack under the Fifth... the equal protection aspects of the Fifth Amendment, just like a Fourteenth Amendment case, which is what this really is.

Secondly, you would have to test it under the Tenth Amendment, because this Court recognized in cases like New York v. United States, Gregory and Ashcroft, that there is a certain core of State authority that really is sacrosanct.
And finally--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: More specifically, gives you the power to override that State authority if it exists under 10.
Section 4 says specifically that Congress can make or alter such regulations.

turn.speaker: john_g_kester
turn.label: Mr. John G. Kester
turn.text: --Right, but we're talking now, as I understood it, Justice Scalia, we're talking about Congress just acting in the first instance, and I'm saying the reason Congress could not do this just by itself in the first instance, say we're going to pass a statute imposing term limits, is furthermore that you have another provision which we haven't talked about yet this morning, and that's Article I, section 2, Clause 1, and that says the people shall choose their representatives in the House of Representatives.
If Congress did that, Congress would be acting diametrically opposed to what the people have done.
Now, this is all hypothetical.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Let me ask you about the Tenth Amendment, before we get--

turn.speaker: john_g_kester
turn.label: Mr. John G. Kester
turn.text: Surely.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --too far away from that.

turn.speaker: john_g_kester
turn.label: Mr. John G. Kester
turn.text: Surely.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: If that is the source of the State's power that you assert would justify this piece of legislation, then I assume that the State could also say that the State's electors shall not vote for a President who, in addition to having the qualifications set forth in Article II of the Constitution, has certain other qualifications.
Could the State do that?

turn.speaker: john_g_kester
turn.label: Mr. John G. Kester
turn.text: Now we're talking about a different provision of the Constitution.
That's Article II.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Yes, we are--

turn.speaker: john_g_kester
turn.label: Mr. John G. Kester
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --but the Tenth Amendment hasn't changed.
It's still there.

turn.speaker: john_g_kester
turn.label: Mr. John G. Kester
turn.text: Right, but I--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: If they can add conditions to whom its citizens may vote for for their representatives, why may it not add conditions to the person for whom its electors may vote for as President?

turn.speaker: john_g_kester
turn.label: Mr. John G. Kester
turn.text: --Justice Scalia, I would say that the Tenth Amendment applies differently in different situations, and you have to--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Oh, that's very convenient, but I don't know why.
[Laughter]

turn.speaker: john_g_kester
turn.label: Mr. John G. Kester
turn.text: --Because the question would be, in your case of the presidential electors, it's like the case of Williams v. Rhodes.

Ohio came in there and said, we have very broad authority on how we select presidential electors, don't tell us how we do it, we'll decide that, and this Court said, wait a second, there are other provisions of the Constitution, and the Fourteenth Amendment is generally sufficient.
The important thing is that the State's authority draws on several sources, not just Article I, section 4.
It draws on the Tenth Amendment.
The States started out with the authority to do this.
They didn't have to be granted it at all.
They started it out.
It was reserved.
They also were the people of the State, and remember, it's the people who acted here.
This was--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But the test of whatever the State does, did I understand you to say that it could be overridden by Congress, but Congress has to come second?

turn.speaker: john_g_kester
turn.label: Mr. John G. Kester
turn.text: --The Congress--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Whether the State is acting under the Tenth Amendment, or whatever source.

turn.speaker: john_g_kester
turn.label: Mr. John G. Kester
turn.text: --I believe, Justice Ginsburg, that the proper understanding of section 4 is that was the check that the Framers intended to place on the States.
They were very worried about what kind of election laws the States would pass.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Well then, time, place, and manner is not a limitation, as you see it.
It includes what one might think of as time, place, and manner, plus qualifications, including age 60 is the limit--

turn.speaker: john_g_kester
turn.label: Mr. John G. Kester
turn.text: Any of those things which would be Fourteenth Amendment issues, yes.
Manner was a word that essentially was unlimited, and that was why Article I, section 4 was so controversial.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --So we should forget all about the way we use time, place, and manner in the context of the First Amendment where it's a limited category of things that don't go to the core of free expression, but here you say it covers everything.

turn.speaker: john_g_kester
turn.label: Mr. John G. Kester
turn.text: Here we're construing specific language in the Constitution, and it's different, and the power given to Congress was broad enough to do whatever was necessary to keep the States from passing inappropriate legislation.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: But I don't see why it isn't also broad enough to authorize Congress to act in the first instance.

turn.speaker: john_g_kester
turn.label: Mr. John G. Kester
turn.text: It is... Justice Souter, in the first instance, it may well be, but then Congress is checked in a number of ways, and in some ways that the State isn't, particularly if you look--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: You mean by other provisions of the--

turn.speaker: john_g_kester
turn.label: Mr. John G. Kester
turn.text: --By other provisions.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --Yes.

turn.speaker: john_g_kester
turn.label: Mr. John G. Kester
turn.text: And in particular, Article I, section 2, Clause 1, which here is a source of the State's power, an independent source of the State's power, but when Congress acts, it becomes a restriction, if anything, on Congress' power, because there you have Congress going in and saying to the people of the State, you can't do what you want.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well, if that is a restriction, it just negates... it just negates section 4.

turn.speaker: john_g_kester
turn.label: Mr. John G. Kester
turn.text: To that... to that--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Whatever the people--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --do is okay, so... right?

turn.speaker: john_g_kester
turn.label: Mr. John G. Kester
turn.text: --No.
No, not at all, sir.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: You can't possibly read it that broadly, or it negates section 4.

turn.speaker: john_g_kester
turn.label: Mr. John G. Kester
turn.text: No.
In that particular case it might, yes.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: So long as the people of a State vote for this time, place, and manner restriction, Congress can't do anything about it.

turn.speaker: john_g_kester
turn.label: Mr. John G. Kester
turn.text: We're... no, no, no, no.
I'm sorry, I--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: That's what I thought you were saying.

turn.speaker: john_g_kester
turn.label: Mr. John G. Kester
turn.text: --I did not express myself clearly, then.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Or I didn't understand clearly, I guess.

turn.speaker: john_g_kester
turn.label: Mr. John G. Kester
turn.text: Well, whatever--
[Laughter]
Congress has power, I would urge upon the Court, and I think that this is very, very clear when you look at the history of Article I, section 4.
Congress has power granted there, controversial power... a lot of them didn't like it... to go in and say, we don't like your State election law.
They don't even have to say it's unconstitutional.
All they have to say is, we--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: May I ask this question to be sure I understand your theory?
I understand you're saying, if it's a time, place, and manner regulation adopted by the State, the Congress can modify it.
Now, supposing it's a qualification.
There are two ways we can look at the Arkansas law, and assume they take it to be a qualification rather than a ballot access matter, could Congress amend that?

turn.speaker: john_g_kester
turn.label: Mr. John G. Kester
turn.text: --Well, yes, I think they could, because otherwise you're driven, and this is where some of the argument--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But then you're adopting the Attorney General's position that a manner includes a qualification.

turn.speaker: john_g_kester
turn.label: Mr. John G. Kester
turn.text: --What I'm saying is, yes, manner is the broad word... that's the hook--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Which includes qualifications?

turn.speaker: john_g_kester
turn.label: Mr. John G. Kester
turn.text: --Surely.
It has to, because otherwise as I believe Justice--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, it doesn't have to.
One can say qualifications are things like being over 50, and manner things like where you hold your elections and the like.
One doesn't have to say that, but I can understand that.
But that's your view of the word manner.

turn.speaker: john_g_kester
turn.label: Mr. John G. Kester
turn.text: --Otherwise Article IV, the power of Congress in Article IV would make no sense, because then you'd be in a position, and this is where the Solicitor General's argument leaves you, is saying that Congress would have the power to override minor State laws but not huge--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: It would make no sense unless there is a prohibition upon additional qualifications, in which case it would make perfect sense.

turn.speaker: john_g_kester
turn.label: Mr. John G. Kester
turn.text: --And... and--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: It only would make no sense under your theory of the Constitution.
[Laughter]

turn.speaker: john_g_kester
turn.label: Mr. John G. Kester
turn.text: --And... but I submit that my theory of the Constitution, Justice Scalia, has historical validity and makes sense when you--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Under your theory, Mr. Kester, could Congress say that no person shall be a Senator who is not over the age of 25 and have that the controlling qualification?

turn.speaker: john_g_kester
turn.label: Mr. John G. Kester
turn.text: --I... if Congress or the States passed a law that was absolutely flat-out contrary to those provisions in Article I, if they've made it contrary to it, then that would be unconstitutional just on the face of it.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: How about saying no person over 50 under 50, saying... you know, Congress obviously was... the Framers were concerned about age, 35, and you know, we're also concerned about age.
We think it should be 50.
Could that override the 35-year-old provision?

turn.speaker: john_g_kester
turn.label: Mr. John G. Kester
turn.text: I think there you've got legislation going right at the heart of provisions that were put in the Constitution, and it could be that those are minimum qualifications, or it could be that they could be enhanced with respect to age or district residence.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: So what's your answer, under your theory?

turn.speaker: john_g_kester
turn.label: Mr. John G. Kester
turn.text: My answer, sir, is that it would never stand up under the Fifth Amendment, under Article I, section 2.
That--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But it could stand up under the framework we're talking about now, Article I?

turn.speaker: john_g_kester
turn.label: Mr. John G. Kester
turn.text: --Possibly in the first instance, but it hardly matters because it would so clearly violate those other provisions.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Why would it violate those other provisions?
Perfectly reasonable to change the age from 35 to 40, 45.
Why would that violate the Fifth Amendment?

turn.speaker: john_g_kester
turn.label: Mr. John G. Kester
turn.text: Well, I think--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: I just don't understand that.

turn.speaker: john_g_kester
turn.label: Mr. John G. Kester
turn.text: --Well--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: We've held age is not a suspect classification.

turn.speaker: john_g_kester
turn.label: Mr. John G. Kester
turn.text: --I think in that case it would be, and in looking at it as a suspect--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, then the constitutional provision is invalid, the 35-year thing is irrational under your approach.
I don't understand why 40 is any more irrational than 35.

turn.speaker: john_g_kester
turn.label: Mr. John G. Kester
turn.text: --Well, it would have to be judged.
It would have to be judged under the Equal Protection part of the Fifth Amendment.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: And not under the Qualifications Clause?

turn.speaker: john_g_kester
turn.label: Mr. John G. Kester
turn.text: The Qualifications Clauses are there... if a law is enacted that this Court believes contradicts those qualifications, that would be unconstitutional.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: No, it's just merely what I thought was your basic position, that the State has every right to impose additional qualifications if it wants to.

turn.speaker: john_g_kester
turn.label: Mr. John G. Kester
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: And I don't know why 40 years is any different than being an incumbent.

turn.speaker: john_g_kester
turn.label: Mr. John G. Kester
turn.text: Oh, but my position is not that the State can come in and impose any qualification it wants to, it's that the State--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, any reasonable qualification.

turn.speaker: john_g_kester
turn.label: Mr. John G. Kester
turn.text: --Well, any qualification that doesn't violate the other restrictions on the States, the Fourteenth Amendment.
I mean, this--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: I just have to say, I don't see why the 40-year thing would violate the Fourteenth or Fifth Amendment.

turn.speaker: john_g_kester
turn.label: Mr. John G. Kester
turn.text: --I defer to your judgment on that, but the analysis, Justice Stevens, would be an analysis--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, if the analysis takes you to the conclusion it does not violate the Fourteenth, then you'd have to face up to the question--

turn.speaker: john_g_kester
turn.label: Mr. John G. Kester
turn.text: --Yes.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --whether they can have an additional qualification, which is what I thought this case was all about, but you seem to say they cannot have certain additional qualifications.

turn.speaker: john_g_kester
turn.label: Mr. John G. Kester
turn.text: No, I said... I said if they have one that's absolutely contradictory, but if it's not--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, why is 40 contradictory to 35?
It just supplements it--

turn.speaker: john_g_kester
turn.label: Mr. John G. Kester
turn.text: --I'll defer to Your Honor on that.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --Mr. Kester, let's take an age... you can't run after the age of 70, instead of upping the age from 35, a mandatory retirement.
Wouldn't that get you out of your Equal Protection problem?

turn.speaker: john_g_kester
turn.label: Mr. John G. Kester
turn.text: Well, it would be very much like Gregory and Ashcroft, wouldn't it, because that was upheld, a mandatory retirement was held not to violate the Fourteenth Amendment.
Basically--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: So if that was the qualification, nobody can run in this State after the age of 70, the State could do that, and that would be a qualification--

turn.speaker: john_g_kester
turn.label: Mr. John G. Kester
turn.text: --The States have done things like that for 200 years.
That's our point.
The States at the beginning said, not only do you have to be a resident of the State, you have to be a resident of the district.
Now, that's a supplementation, that's a qualification.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --There are States that have said you can't run after the age of so-and-so for Congress?

turn.speaker: john_g_kester
turn.label: Mr. John G. Kester
turn.text: Mm-hmm, and--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: You said States have done that for years, put--

turn.speaker: john_g_kester
turn.label: Mr. John G. Kester
turn.text: --Oh, not... not that, but States have added qualifications since the very beginning, and incidentally, they called them time, place, and manner regulations.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: --Thank you, Mr. Kester.

turn.speaker: john_g_kester
turn.label: Mr. John G. Kester
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Mr. Cohen, we'll hear from you.

turn.speaker: deputy_solicitor_general_louis_r_cohen
turn.label: Mr. Louis R. Cohen
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice, may it please the Court:

My theory of the Constitution, which I think is also Madison's and Hamilton's theory of the Constitution on this point, is that the Constitution deals comprehensively with the filling of the office of the Congress that it created, that it prescribes fixed qualifications that may not be supplemented by either Congress or the States, and that it gives both the States and Congress the power to set time, place, and manner regulations so as to assure fair and orderly elections, but that that is an essentially procedural power, leaving the people at each election to choose whom they please to govern them.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Why didn't they put it differently, then, Mr. Cohen?
The briefs here have been referring to this as a qualifications clause.
It's really not a qualifications clause, it's a disqualifications clause.

They could have said, every person shall be eligible to serve in the House of Representatives who shall attain to the age of 25 years, shall have been 7 years a citizen of the United States, and shall not when elected... and shall be when elected an inhabitant of that State in which he shall be chosen, a very easy way to say it.

turn.speaker: deputy_solicitor_general_louis_r_cohen
turn.label: Mr. Louis R. Cohen
turn.text: Well, of course--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: But they took the circuitous route of saying, no person shall be a representative who shall not have attained the age of 25 years, been 7... in other words, you can't, unless you have these conditions, but that isn't to say that just because you meet these conditions you are eligible.
It does not say that, and John Randolph--

turn.speaker: deputy_solicitor_general_louis_r_cohen
turn.label: Mr. Louis R. Cohen
turn.text: --I agree that the constitutional--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --pointed this out in the first congressional debate on the matter.

turn.speaker: deputy_solicitor_general_louis_r_cohen
turn.label: Mr. Louis R. Cohen
turn.text: --I agree that the constitutional text doesn't resolve the issue because it phrases it that way.

One reason why it may phrase it that way is because there are other disqualifications in the Constitution itself, and there was contemplation, of course, of further possible disqualifications, but when Madison and Hamilton came to explain what the Constitution did, when the House Committee on Elections in 1807 studied the meaning of that clause, they concluded that the intention was to make those qualifications exclusive.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, you say the House Committee on Elections, Mr. Cohen.
Was the House committee's view accepted by the full House?

turn.speaker: deputy_solicitor_general_louis_r_cohen
turn.label: Mr. Louis R. Cohen
turn.text: The full House didn't adopt the report, but I think it did accept the House committee's view.

It voted to seat Congressman McCreary, and it voted to seat Congressman McCreary after a point in the debate when it becomes clear that the dissenter, Mr. Randolph of Virginia, recognized that he was about to lose, and diverted the House debate to a more neutral resolution.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, that's very speculative, isn't it?
I mean, couldn't the full House's result have been also because some people thought that he was in fact a resident of Baltimore, that he complied with the State regulation?

turn.speaker: deputy_solicitor_general_louis_r_cohen
turn.label: Mr. Louis R. Cohen
turn.text: We don't know--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: We simply--

turn.speaker: deputy_solicitor_general_louis_r_cohen
turn.label: Mr. Louis R. Cohen
turn.text: --of course, why anyone voted.
We do know that the understanding at the time, the scholarly understanding of what had been resolved in the McCreary episode was that the--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: --Well, what... how does the fact that the scholarly understanding... does that elevate what actually happened into something different?
[Laughter]

turn.speaker: deputy_solicitor_general_louis_r_cohen
turn.label: Mr. Louis R. Cohen
turn.text: --No, of course not.

Of course not this Court reviewed this history in the Powell case starting with the fact that on August 10, 1787, the question that was being voted on on the floor of the convention was whether to give Congress the power to add a property qualification or to add other qualifications.

This Court said on that day the Court faced and rejected the possibility that the legislature... and it was clearly talking about legislation, and not merely about a judging power... the legislature would have the power to usurp the right of the people to return whom they thought proper.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, now you're not talking about the McCreary case.

turn.speaker: deputy_solicitor_general_louis_r_cohen
turn.label: Mr. Louis R. Cohen
turn.text: Well, I'm... I'm leading up to it.
The Court then went on--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: We've only got 40 minutes.

turn.speaker: deputy_solicitor_general_louis_r_cohen
turn.label: Mr. Louis R. Cohen
turn.text: --Okay.
[Laughter]
I will... let me move on.

But the Court reviewed Hamilton's statement in the Federalist Number 60 that the qualifications were unalterable by the legislature, Madison's statement to the same effect in Number 52, where he is clearly talking about State power to add qualifications.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: More clearly than Hamilton, isn't he?

turn.speaker: deputy_solicitor_general_louis_r_cohen
turn.label: Mr. Louis R. Cohen
turn.text: Well, I think Hamilton, when he referred to the legislature, was referring to Congress, but I think Madison is talking about the States.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: What was the... do you remember the phrase in 52?
I can't remember the text that you're referring to.
You said it clearly refers to the States.

turn.speaker: deputy_solicitor_general_louis_r_cohen
turn.label: Mr. Louis R. Cohen
turn.text: Well--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: If it does, he was making a mistake, wasn't he, because he also was excluding the States' power to change the qualifications of electors--

turn.speaker: deputy_solicitor_general_louis_r_cohen
turn.label: Mr. Louis R. Cohen
turn.text: --No.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --which it obviously could.

turn.speaker: deputy_solicitor_general_louis_r_cohen
turn.label: Mr. Louis R. Cohen
turn.text: No.
What he was doing in 52 was explaining how the Constitution had fixed both the qualifications for voters and the qualifications for the elected.
It fixed the qualifications for voters by delegating that to the States subject to the most numerous branch compromise requirement.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: That's not much of a fixing.
The fact is, the States could change it so long as they were willing to change it for their most numerous branch of the legislature.

turn.speaker: deputy_solicitor_general_louis_r_cohen
turn.label: Mr. Louis R. Cohen
turn.text: Madison uses the word 52--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Why say it's a mistake?

turn.speaker: deputy_solicitor_general_louis_r_cohen
turn.label: Mr. Louis R. Cohen
turn.text: --in relation to... in relation to the State constitutional provisions on this point, and he says that... in effect that these are fixed because the States and the people of the States won't allow changes in State provisions for voting for the most numerous branch of the State legislature, so we've dealt with that problem.
I would like to move on to the State's principal contention, which is, we didn't do that.
We just barred these people whom--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Before you do that--

turn.speaker: deputy_solicitor_general_louis_r_cohen
turn.label: Mr. Louis R. Cohen
turn.text: --we'd like to disqualify--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --Mr. Cohen, may I ask whether in your view we owe any kind of precedential respect to the interpretation of history in Powell v. McCormack?
We're not dealing here with a new discovery by Professor Warren, we're dealing with what has already gone over.
Mr. Kester has told us that... that perhaps some of the statements there, some of the conclusions weren't quite right, that there was room for other interpretations.

turn.speaker: deputy_solicitor_general_louis_r_cohen
turn.label: Mr. Louis R. Cohen
turn.text: --I think that Powell is a very persuasive opinion, and the Court should find it persuasive.
I also think there is substantial additional evidence on our side of this point that wasn't reviewed or reached in Powell.
I think--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Did Powell at this point purport to go beyond the decision whether Congress or a House of Congress could act?
It seems to me that it did not--

turn.speaker: deputy_solicitor_general_louis_r_cohen
turn.label: Mr. Louis R. Cohen
turn.text: --It seems to me--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --and it seems to me that that's the limitation... with the possible exception of your reference to 52, which I'm not sure of, that seems to me the problem with some of the, or at least the limitation on the cites to the debate text and say, Federalist 60.
It's clearly referring, by legislature, to the national legislature, and it seems to me that you're supporting legislative history, as it were, doesn't take you beyond the limitation on Congress.

turn.speaker: deputy_solicitor_general_louis_r_cohen
turn.label: Mr. Louis R. Cohen
turn.text: --The... it seems to me that Powell rests on the proposition that the qualifications were fixed in the Constitution and could not be supplemented legislatively.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, I think you're mistaken on that, Mr. Cohen.
The holding of Powell clearly has to be that a single House of Congress cannot add to the qualifications otherwise legitimately set.

turn.speaker: deputy_solicitor_general_louis_r_cohen
turn.label: Mr. Louis R. Cohen
turn.text: Yes, but as this Court explained in the Judge Nixon case, the basis for that holding was not an aspect of the judging power as such, it was the fact that the... or that Article I, section 2, fixed qualifications that could be applied.
There are two questions here.
One is, vis-a-vis Congress, are we talking only about a judging power, or are we also talking about the power to legislate additional qualifications?
It seems to me every point in argument that was made in Powell goes to the power to legislate, not to the power to judge, although the ultimate question was only whether Congress could judge.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: And so the ultimate holding, wasn't it?

turn.speaker: deputy_solicitor_general_louis_r_cohen
turn.label: Mr. Louis R. Cohen
turn.text: The ultimate holding, I agree, but the logical foundation was that, and it then seems to me that the extension to the States is straightforward.
In the first place, some of the examples that the Court used in Powell were State additions of qualifications, or attempts by States to add qualifications.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: But it can't possibly be straightforward, because Congress would need to have been given the power to make the alteration.
That power would have had to be found within the Constitution.
With respect to the States, that is not true.
With respect to the States you have the main thing that's relied on here, the Tenth Amendment.
There's nothing in Powell about the Tenth Amendment, is there?
We didn't even consider the Tenth Amendment.

turn.speaker: deputy_solicitor_general_louis_r_cohen
turn.label: Mr. Louis R. Cohen
turn.text: I agree that I need to go on to talk about those points.
I don't think that the Tenth Amendment reserves--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: We're going to have you do that, but you're trying to not have to do it by saying--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --we've decided it--

turn.speaker: deputy_solicitor_general_louis_r_cohen
turn.label: Mr. Louis R. Cohen
turn.text: --No, no, no.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --already in Powell.

turn.speaker: deputy_solicitor_general_louis_r_cohen
turn.label: Mr. Louis R. Cohen
turn.text: No.
I'm only saying that I think Powell did dispose of additional qualifications.

I don't think the... and I think that if you read the admittedly not clear and dispositive constitutional text as a preclusive list, there's simply no logical reason to think that it is preclusive vis-a-vis Congress and not preclusive vis-a-vis the States.

But I think this is not a Tenth Amendment case, because the Constitution doesn't leave the States or Congress the power to bar or to officially and materially prefer some qualified candidates over others.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, Mr. Cohen, we have Storer, for example, which certainly prevented a candidate from appearing on a ballot at least for a period of time.
We did not treat that as a qualification, did we?

turn.speaker: deputy_solicitor_general_louis_r_cohen
turn.label: Mr. Louis R. Cohen
turn.text: That's right.
Storer--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: And so in theory this provision may not be a qualification at all.

turn.speaker: deputy_solicitor_general_louis_r_cohen
turn.label: Mr. Louis R. Cohen
turn.text: --No.

The fact that Storer said that the States have power to regulate access to the ballot in order to provide for fair and orderly elections, or as in that case, in order to preserve the integrity of the various routes to the ballot so as to give people a choice, doesn't mean that the States may impose ballot access limitations based on place of birth or civil profession or prior service in the State legislature or prior service in Congress, or being under the age of 70.
The Constitution--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Those things, if you do it on those bases it converts itself from a time, place, and manner restriction to a qualification?

turn.speaker: deputy_solicitor_general_louis_r_cohen
turn.label: Mr. Louis R. Cohen
turn.text: --Yes.
I think the--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: If it's a qualification, I assume that the House would sit in judgment of whether that qualification was met.

turn.speaker: deputy_solicitor_general_louis_r_cohen
turn.label: Mr. Louis R. Cohen
turn.text: --I do not think that either the States or Congress may add qualifications.
I'm happy to use the term qualification in the sense in which you suggested earlier, Justice Scalia, which is qualifications is something that--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: You can't serve if you don't have it.

turn.speaker: deputy_solicitor_general_louis_r_cohen
turn.label: Mr. Louis R. Cohen
turn.text: --that says you can't serve if you don't have it.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: And that's not the case here.

turn.speaker: deputy_solicitor_general_louis_r_cohen
turn.label: Mr. Louis R. Cohen
turn.text: That is not the case here, but the State also may not keep off the ballot in order to disadvantage somebody who lacks a substantive personal characteristic because the Constitution leaves those questions to the voters every second year.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well, maybe, but certainly not because the State is adding an additional qualification.
I mean, it may be bad, but not for the reason that it's violating the presumably exclusive Qualifications Clause.

turn.speaker: deputy_solicitor_general_louis_r_cohen
turn.label: Mr. Louis R. Cohen
turn.text: I will accept that with this exception.
I think the Arkansas supreme court was justified in saying here this measure is impermissible for essentially the same reason.

That is to say, the lawmakers of Arkansas, the people, were told, and then they said in the measure that they adopted, that the measure limited the terms of public officials, and the Arkansas supreme court simply rejected the argument that something that did that, that tried to impose a qualification, if you will, could be saved on the argument that it just might not achieve its stated purpose because of a loophole, the write-in loophole that has no significant history of working.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: May I just go back to Storer for a moment?
Could you just state for me the criteria, the standard on which you would have us distinguish the Storer disability, we'll say, from this disability?

turn.speaker: deputy_solicitor_general_louis_r_cohen
turn.label: Mr. Louis R. Cohen
turn.text: Yes.

Storer involved a legitimate time, place, and manner regulation designed to produce a fair and orderly election with a manageable ballot so that the people of California could choose by saying people who want to run in a prim... to be in a party in connection with a particular election must run in that party's primary and be the party's candidate.
People who want to run as independents must leave a party early enough to assure the genuineness of their independence and the nonfracturing of the party.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Orderly elections.
It's orderly elections that's--

turn.speaker: deputy_solicitor_general_louis_r_cohen
turn.label: Mr. Louis R. Cohen
turn.text: It's orderly elections.

Now, it's quite different from... it's... if I can use a metaphor, it's like the difference between saying that someone must run in his assigned, qualifying heat in order to get into the finals of the 100-yard dash, and saying that somebody who won the medal last time must start 50 yards behind the others because we want to pass the medals around.

One involves procedural regulation that the Constitution authorizes the States to do, and the other involves a State substantive preference for one class of candidates over another that I think is not part of the entire scheme that is spelled out in some detail in the Constitution.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: --You justify sore-loser statutes on the basis that they are procedural.

turn.speaker: deputy_solicitor_general_louis_r_cohen
turn.label: Mr. Louis R. Cohen
turn.text: Yes, and there's a good deal of, in addition to text, legislative history that supports this reading.
If you read, particularly the Federalist 59 and 60.
Now, petitioners aren't very clear, to say the least, about whether the State's supposed power here is... is a power granted by the Time, Place, and Manner Clause or by the Tenth Amendment.
I suggest the reason that they're not very clear is that neither argument works.

The Constitution explicitly gives Congress the superior power to make election regulations or to alter those of the States, but it plainly, in doing so, means to limit the power of both the States and Congress to procedural matters.

It seems to me that the argument that a State can impose ballot access restrictions under some power outside the Time, Place, and Manner Clause is answered in the clause itself, which contains the phrase, "make or alter", and incidentally, the primary reason for that phrase was a fear that the States might not set up the machinery for congressional elections at all, and so the "make" part of the "make or alter" phrase is an important part of it.

The convention deliberately gave Congress the power to make or alter State regulations because Hamilton said an exclusive power of regulating elections for the national Government in the hands of the State legislatures would leave the Union entirely at their mercy.
That's the Federalist Number 59.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Mr. Cohen, what is your view as to whether something can be neither the one nor the other, neither a qualification nor a time, place, and manner restriction?
Is there some--

turn.speaker: deputy_solicitor_general_louis_r_cohen
turn.label: Mr. Louis R. Cohen
turn.text: I don't... if you mean by that something--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --Some restriction that is--

turn.speaker: deputy_solicitor_general_louis_r_cohen
turn.label: Mr. Louis R. Cohen
turn.text: --permissible--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --Something... no, not permissible.

turn.speaker: deputy_solicitor_general_louis_r_cohen
turn.label: Mr. Louis R. Cohen
turn.text: --Well--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Something that... whether it's permissible or not, is there anything that does not fall within one or the other category?
I gathered from your answer to my earlier question that you thought that there wasn't.
This might, indeed, be it.

turn.speaker: deputy_solicitor_general_louis_r_cohen
turn.label: Mr. Louis R. Cohen
turn.text: --No, I think--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: You say it's impermissible, but not because it is technically a qualification.

turn.speaker: deputy_solicitor_general_louis_r_cohen
turn.label: Mr. Louis R. Cohen
turn.text: --That's right.
That's right.
I think there can be--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: But it's also not a time, place, and manner.

turn.speaker: deputy_solicitor_general_louis_r_cohen
turn.label: Mr. Louis R. Cohen
turn.text: --That's right.
That's right.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: So it is a third something-or-other, but an impermissible third--

turn.speaker: deputy_solicitor_general_louis_r_cohen
turn.label: Mr. Louis R. Cohen
turn.text: That's right.

I think for a State to say, on the whole we don't think people over 70 ought to continue to serve unless their constituents really want them, and so we'll keep them off the ballot, but if they can win by a write-in that's okay.
I think that is not a valid time, place, and manner regulation.
I also would not urge that anyone call it a qualification for the reason you point out, that it is merely keeping someone off the ballot.
I would then carve out an exception for that point for the--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --Are you abandoning the position of the Arkansas supreme court that it was a qualification?

turn.speaker: deputy_solicitor_general_louis_r_cohen
turn.label: Mr. Louis R. Cohen
turn.text: --I think what... I'm--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Yes or no.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Because that was part of the rationale of their decision.

turn.speaker: deputy_solicitor_general_louis_r_cohen
turn.label: Mr. Louis R. Cohen
turn.text: --I am... I am reading... if that's the premise as to what it says, my answer's no.
As to what Arkansas said, my answer is yes, I disagree with that.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: You're conceding that this is not a qualification in this case?

turn.speaker: deputy_solicitor_general_louis_r_cohen
turn.label: Mr. Louis R. Cohen
turn.text: I am arguing that it was appropriate for the Arkansas supreme court to say is does--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: I understand that, but are you conceding that it's not a qualification?

turn.speaker: deputy_solicitor_general_louis_r_cohen
turn.label: Mr. Louis R. Cohen
turn.text: --I'm willing to... yes.
Yes.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: It's a rather major concession.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: That's not, as I--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --It's a very reasonable one, Mr. Cohen.
[Laughter]

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: That's not how I understood your brief.
Your first argument is the Constitution bars States and Congress from adding to the qualifications for service in Congress.

turn.speaker: deputy_solicitor_general_louis_r_cohen
turn.label: Mr. Louis R. Cohen
turn.text: I think that's important, and I don't think that I've made a significant concession.
